formats.name: visual_metaphor
formats.instruction: Describe a complex idea using a visual metaphor or analogy. One sentence only, be poetic but clear. No explanations afterwards.

formats.name: rapid_fire_reactions
formats.instruction: List 5 super-brief gut reactions to a hot topic. Each reaction is 1 sentence, and the total post must not exceed 30 words. Go for punchy and bold.

formats.name: microhistory
formats.instruction: Tell a fascinating microhistory about something overlooked. Write as if you're narrating to a friend at a party. 1-2 paragraphs, vivid details favored.

formats.name: interview_yourself
formats.instruction: Write 3 Q&A pairs as if you're interviewing yourself on a weird or personal topic. Each answer should surprise, amuse, or provoke.

formats.name: future_snapshot
formats.instruction: Imagine it's ten years from now. Write a short dispatch (as if reporting live) about how something in culture, tech, or society has changed. Paint vividly.

formats.name: poetic_blueprint
formats.instruction: Create a poetic, step-by-step blueprint for achieving something. Use metaphor and unexpected imagery in each step. Minimum 4 steps.

formats.name: contrarian_playbook
formats.instruction: Lay out a contrarian roadmap for a familiar topic—what would you do if going against all common advice? 3-5 numbered tactics elaborated in 1-2 sentences each.

formats.name: epiphany_chain
formats.instruction: Write about a topic by chaining together 3 evolving epiphanies, each building on the last. Keep it sequential and surprising.

formats.name: unexpected_case_for
formats.instruction: Make an unexpected case FOR something most people dismiss or dislike. Start with a bold opening, then build a 1-paragraph defense.

formats.name: myth_vs_reality_scene
formats.instruction: Write a mini-dialogue between 'Myth' and 'Reality' about a common misconception. 4 exchanges max, each exchange less than 2 sentences.

title_styles: Write your title as a headline for a tabloid—make it mysterious, provocative, and impossible not to click.
Start your title with a question, then twist it in a surprising direction. Examples: 'Can pigeons teach us about AI?'
Write a title as an urgent warning. Examples: 'Why ignoring X might be your biggest mistake yet', 'The ticking time bomb nobody sees in Y'
Use a metaphor or simile in the title. Examples: 'X is like playing chess underwater', 'Think of Y as your personal Swiss army knife'
Make your title sound like the opening line of a sci-fi novel. Examples: 'On the day the algorithms learned to dream...', 'After the last analog signal faded...'
structure_variants: Write as an imagined overheard conversation among three wildly different personalities.
Begin with a fable, then tie it back to the real world topic with clear lessons.
Present your content as a series of hypothetical 'what if' scenarios, escalating in absurdity.
Frame everything as a decision tree—each point leads to a branching choice.
Write in alternating perspectives: one paragraph optimistic, one pessimistic, repeat.
